723726f-a.text:
(1)
Varick Street, east side, between Beach and Laight Streets, showing the front of St. John's Chapel, P.E. The railing here shown, was brought from England. The church has been demolished and on its site stands now (1937) station V of the United States Post Office. For a rear view of the Church,see York Street, west from West Broadway to
St. Eohns Lane.
About 1914.
OOift of Samuel Landsman.
(2)
The same, showing a closer view of the front entrance.
About 1914.
Gift o  f Samue  wwY as aaR(6im47'~.
(3)
A portion of the same, showing the gate to the south church yard.
About 1914.
Cift of Samuel Landsnwn.

varick Street, east side, at Beach Street. Also shown is No. 19 Beach treet, adjoining the N.E. (empty lot) corner of Varick Street. The 10-story warehouse shown on the left, is No. 30-32 Varick Street, and has an ell,
No. 17-11 Beach Street.
April 2, 1932.
P. L. Sperr.

723721f-a.text:
Varick Street, east side, at Beach Street, as seen from Hudson Street, and across the former site of the New York Central Freight Depot. 9-e The small 3-story building on the right, is the 4th Precinct Police Station,
and is at the S.W. corner of Ericsson Place (Beach Street).
December 5, 1936.
P. L. Sperr.
723721f-a.folder: Varick Street & Beach Street, Manhattan, NY

723725f-a.text:

the Sixth Ave. Elevated Line on West Broadway.
About 1935.
Louis H. Dreyer.
723725f-a.folder: Varick Street & Beach Street, Manhattan, NY

719645f-a.text:
20 to 42 Ericsson Place (Beach Street) south side, west from but not including Varick (left) to Hudson (right) Streets, as seen across clearance (former site of St. John's Depot) at the N.E. corner of Hudson Street and Ericsson Place. The small white building (No. 20) on the extreme left is the 4th Precinct Police Station and is at the S.W. corner of Varick Street. Shown on the right is an extensive view southward on Hudson Street from Laight Street. John Ericsson, the inventor and builder of the famous war-vessel "Monitor" resided at one time at what was No. 30 Beach Street and in his honor this portion which contained his house has been named Ericsson Place. The site would be in the center,directly in front
of the chimney tower shown.
May 20, 1937.
719645f-a.folder: Ericsson Place & Varick Street, Manhattan, NY

719647f-a.text:
36 Ericsson Place (formerly Beach Street), south side, between Varick and Hudson Street's, showing the home of Capt. John Ericsson of Civil War fame(the Monitor). This portion of Beach Street was changed to Ericsson Place in 1939, to honor and commemorate his achievements.
About 1905
Gift of Urbrock Collection

AAbout 1935.
